What's interesting, having to deal with two men who had smoked dope one day this week, was that neither could hold a conversation on a subject for more than one or two interchanges.
This is what turned me off to it in 10th grade. Users may eagerly anticipate upcoming experience, but cannot focus on it when it happens.
Their reflexes and responses are slow, flawed, absent.
The same two users a couple days ago, reflect the conflation occurring in descriptions:
It does NOT confer euphoria. Both, along with the entire history of other under the influence, display notable negative affect, being pessimistic when not stoned. That pesimism tends to lead to exteriorization of blame - that is, to evaluate some person, stereotypical group, or event as vaguely guilty of inimical effect.

This may be relatively accurate in a few cases, but is such a pervasive outlook among the users, that i've found it to consistently create eror of attribution of others.
Incredible bias shows up in their conversation, and the whole illusion of euphoria is clearly falsified within seconds or minutes.

Sure, expectation of euphoria happens, creating a placebo effect: it never lasts.
There is a lot of correlation with depression as well.

Compare the molecule structure of the endogeneous cannabinoid receptor (e.g. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anandamide ) with THC - it's nothing alike (very similar to alcohol). This is called structure-activity-paradox in pharmacology.

PS: in fact, all molecules docking on the cannabinoid receptor (like THC, anandamide and JWH-018 - a synthetic cannabinoid very dissimilar in structure to the former two) have something in common, and these are long carbon chains. These are also the reason that all cannabinoids are liposoluble.

Resembles, resembles, resembles,! Not the same. What a joke weed does indeed do more harm than good to the average person. I am not talking about those who seriously use it for real health issues. I am talking about the majority not the minority of users! The majority of everyday users smoke weed to feel a sense of joy and happiness. They become dependent on that "wake n bake" to start their day out right. If they cant bake right away that person will become moody, irritated, and not at all pleasant to be around!Eventually when their high goes away they are left feeling empty and cannot wait to smoke again.

The positive health benefits for the majority of smokers is a mental thing. They feel a sense of satisfaction that they cannot get enough of. It calms their anxiety and nerves. Blah,blah,blah. Well here is the absolute truth. I use to smoke and even made excuses well, it helps my back pain. Well, thanks to my faith in Christ Jesus I don't need weed to feel satisfied. I don't need weed to bring me joy and happiness. I don't need weed to calm my anxiety. His Holy Spirit comes into you and gives you strength to live a life of holiness, godliness, and righteousness;). Jesus Christ is the only way to God and the only source of everlasting life in Heaven:)!

Since my faith in Christ Jesus I am no longer a slave to sin. Jesus gives me the strength to please our Heavenly Father more than my fleshly desires (which are sinful). Do I still sin even though I am a Christian? Yes, lol we all do. Jesus was the only one who was ever without sin He came to earth to destroy the works of the devil. Thats why He was God made flesh. God loved the world so much that He His only begotten son that whosoever believes in Him will not perish but have everlasting life:)! God loves us. Your spouse may not truly love you. Your friends may not always love you. Your mom and dad may not show you love. Your brothers or sisters may not love you. You may feel the world does not love you.

I am proof and telling you that there is someone who loves you unconditionally. He says in His Word that He is your brother and friend. His name is Jesus and the Bible says Jesus sticks to those who believe in Him closer than a brother:)! We can't live righteous and holy lives without Jesus. He says if we repent of our sins. He will forgive us of our sins. He says he will give us the strength to live or lives for God. His Holy Spirit that he gives us power to live righteous and holy and to do right. He gives us love so we can show the same love toward all people that God has shown us. He gives us self control through His Holy Spirit to be able to do whats right and be set free from slavery of sin;)!

In the midst of a crazy time. I have never had so much love, joy, and peace. It's not from drugs, alcohol, entertainment, technology, materials, money, my job, my wife or anything else this broken world has to offer. No my love, joy, and peace comes from faith in my Lord Jesus Christ and He is the only one who brings me happiness:)! You can take everything away from me but no one can separate me from my Lord and Saviour Jesus. God's Word promises so much for the believer. His Word is truth and it is powerful and living.

Anyone can have what I have its free:)! A person is saved by grace through faith in Christ Jesus. The grace of God our Creator saved us only when a person repents and believes that Jesus Christ is the Son of God. Its totally surrendering to Jesus giving Him everything. Give Him your hurt, your shame, your fears, your anxieties, your addictions, your sinful lifestyle, your heart, your soul, and your mind. Give it to Jesus and what you get in return is unspeakable joy, love that is beyond anything of this world, and peace that surpasses all understanding :)!

You become a new person when you put God first in your life:)! You won't want to live as a slave to sin! You won't want to please your fleshly desires more than your spiritual desires. You will want to please God more than the world. You may not be popular but you have a family of brothers and sisters in Christ Jesus and we are here for eacother to encourage and love one another. God gives us a choice we have free will. Just as in the beginning in the garden of Eden. Adam and Eve had a choice to to obey the only commandment God gave them. That was they could not eat from the tree of knowledge of good and evil. If they did they would surely die.

As a long term weed smoker, I used to smoke because of my anxiety and deep depression but come to find out it actually made things worse! Yeah it makes you high for the moment and "forget" but as soon as that buzz goes away anxiety and depression hits even harder making you crave it even more and more causing you to have addiction and actually start depending on it, thinking "its the only thing that'll make me feel better now". I was wrong for years having that mindset, realizing the more I got used to it over the years the worse my depression thoughts and paranoia got. Also realizing how much brain cells I've actually lost over the years and how it keeps you at a certain mindset. I was a stoner big time but there came a time where I've realized how dependent I got on it and how it controlled me and my thoughts for a very long time. Quitting it was SO HARD but come to realize it was the BEST decision I've pushed myself to make, realizing how my thoughts actually became more positive then when I was on it and for years couldn't get rid of my depression & how being sober and actually dealing with your shit without using anything makes you so much more powerful in life. I hope somebody can really relate to my story and actually do what's best to change their life to the better ❤️

When I’m baked I get auditory hallucinations, like I can hear my family talking downstairs even though it’s 3am and they’re all asleep. You get a sort of tunnel vision, where the outer edges of your eyesight are out of view. I get some twitching in my limbs, mostly my legs. Everything feels like it’s so slow but time actually passes very quickly. You get a sort of short term memory loss - when I’m in a conversation with someone, I will often forget what we were even talking about halfway through. Music sounds so full and deep, the most high quality you’ve ever heard. Obviously food is fantastic. You sort of crave water because of the dry mouth but you’re really not thirsty. When you get the munchies, you don’t feel actual hunger, your brain just starts telling you that food sounds absolutely amazing right now, and your mouth waters.

Wow.. well I'm going to say something here and a lot of people are not going to believe me and are going to think I'm crazy for saying it but here goes. I'm in my late 50s and when I was younger I smoked pot once in a while maybe about 20 times in my life. They said it's natural they said that God gave it to us and we should smoke it etc etc I've heard every story out there and I've been told that it's okay to grow your own put it in the oven and dry it and do all that stuff. However over the years after I quit smoking that stuff in my twenties I have noticed enormous changes in my friends from the past and they are either bipolar schizophrenic diagnosed with these diseases all of them cannot hold down a job a lot of them are on welfare some have committed suicide after smoking pot a lot of them got killed in an auto accident after smoking pot so I did some research and I said there has to be something bad about marijuana. And everybody should look at the fact it does destroy the brain cells.
Now I understand that young people want to try it but it is so addicting after while and people will say I can quit when I want you know it's almost impossible if they don't put a lot of effort into it and determination to get off of it. And some say there's no reason to and they don't want to well that's their prerogative. But the worst time to ever smoke marijuana is while you're young when your brain is developing from youth until your 20 or 21 because it interferes with the hormones it interferes with the firing system of the brain. Be wise and think about the consequences Watch what it does to other people. Have enough sense and if you're having a bad time with your parents you can't communicate with the parents because your parents are jerks then go to a counselor a good counselor not somebody your own age because they may think they know what's best for you but they don't live your life with your parents. Take care of yourself everybody who smokes this stuff but I would strongly suggest you do some research. I've known guys who can never have children again. All I could think of while I did pot for the first time the other day was... is this what it feels like to die? It wasn't terrible... It just felt like nothingness, something so foreign, it could only be possible to feel such a way If I was slowly dying. I felt like all the lights where going out and I no longer had control of my thoughts, they seemed to wiz on past me before I could give consent. It wasn't terrible or even bad... It was just so completely foreign that I was absolutely panicking. Once I came to my senses again, I tried to talk to the people around me, and even though I was screaming they all told me they could barely hear my voice. Or at least, my voice echoing in my brain seemed like screams. Turns out I had taken HUGE DEEP BREATHS of it instead of little puffs for my first time. It only took 3 to do the job, and the weird thing was, I don't remember how I was reacting to it outside of my thoughts and attempts to communicate with people, but they all said they'd never seen anyone react to the drug in that way. So I kinda overdosed, even though with a drug like pot, it technically isn't possible to overdose. You cannot harm youself by doing too much pot, but you can do it so much to a point where it is so extreme it isn't enjoyable. I might consider doing it again, maybe next time I'll know what the heck is going on instead of thinking it was the end of the world, but we'll see. It was a crazy ride, and I feel like it deffinatelly isn't harmful at all besides maybe scaring the s**t out of you, and if that is a bad thing horror movies should be banned too lol

@Nicole Castillo, I totally disagree with you on LSD. LSD while a far more psychedelic and mind-altering drug, does not pose significant dangers in terms of addiction, physiological harm or social degradation. In fact it, along with other classical psychedelics, has an inherent tolerance building effer which generally prevents frequent trips. Whilst certainly capable of aiding a euphoric experienc, LSD does not make you comfortable in a way that is easily craved. People have taken 30-1,000 times the normal dosage (according to some accounts) and had little to speak of in the way of long term harm. For a large number of people, it is an elucidating, beautiful experience which allows reality to be understood in ways that it seems almost unbelieveable to have been without for so long. It is heinous to see LSD lumped in with the most dangerous drugs when I see it as being a potential springboard for positive, nootropic drug use.

For others, it may be a horrifying experience, but the important thing to remember is that it simply modifies an existing mental environment. Negative experiences can only stem from internal negativity. To put it simply, the more misconceptions you harbour, the more shocking the experience may be.

When I smoke weed, it takes about ten minuted for it to kick in. Just one hit from a bong is plenty for me to get high. To give a little insight on how I feel when high, first things first: It is literally the best feeling I have ever had in my life, with no crash or unpleasant come down. Something that happens to me when I am on it is things that normally induce fear no longer induce fear. Like being in the woods at night, going up high, spiders, stuff like that. None of it bothers me when I am high. When high, I lose seconds. Not minutes or huge amounts of time, at maximum a few seconds. It isn't scary though, it gives you an odd feeling and makes you think deeper. Closing my eyes....well, let's just say I get some crazy imagery going on when I do that, but everything is always pleasant and enjoyable. I get an incredible feeling of euphoria, this is the absolute best part during my highs. The euphoria comes as feeling overall very happy and comfortable, and waves of extremely pleasant tickling sensations all over my body that make me smile largely or even twitch and laugh.

If you are looking for a great experience, try some. Though everyone feels different when high. One of my friends tried it and got extremely paranoid and scared, he said he will never do it again, which is totally fine. I wouldn't if it did that to me. But I am lucky enough to have an amazingly pleasant high, one that gives me the best feeling in the world. I think that weed would be a much more efficient antidepressant than this shit that my therapists recommended.

1:37 to 1:54 was a great description. I presume that people curious and yet to try Cannabis are reading the comments. I want to explain why :37 to :54 is so great but it's so hard until you have tried it.
For me, i was listening to music on my music player while stoned for the first time. Closed my eyes and went on a water slide of colour where i had everything i ever wanted given to me within a period of consecutive moments. Possessions, outcomes and anything else. Pure bliss. My first three or so experiences with cannabis were like that and are to this day my most positive memories ever. It's no surprise i kept doing it. Cannabis is a drug and of course my body soon built up a tolerance. I had to take more and more to achieve even a remotely similar experience to my first few times. Eventually i took an absurd dose to get an unreal feeling like one of my first times and instead i experienced the paranoia properties of cannabis. I was so out of this world that i thought i was going to be murdered. It's been three years since then and to this day while sober i still have strange deja vu like feelings that freak me out and make me feel like my life is a dream and i'm about to be murdered. I'll be at work and have a panic attack and have to go on break to hide it. (I do mild doses of pot about once a month but i don't don't do any other drugs other than alcohol fyi)
Cannabis is a beautiful drug, but don't continue chasing after it's beauty or you'll ruin it like i did. Just be careful. It's cool and all but not to be abused. I abused it and now i can't enjoy it to its maximum potential.

The moment I inhaled I became dizzy because I never smoked (ie nicotine) but after a while I became superperceptive of everything, I laughed even at the most inane jokes my friends were saying, I formulated complex what-if scenarios (like what would happen if police showed up) in matter of seconds, I was able to visualize extremely complex surrealistic shapes without even trying (the shapes ... just came), and when I wanted to tell my friends how awesome it was now that my brain was on THC, I realized that because of the way the drug works I find most things funny. I found that thought funny. I found the thought of the fact that the thought was funny, ironic and funny. That created a seemingly endless positive feedback loop and instead of telling my friends how awesome my brain was on THC I just sat there and I was laughing non-stop for 15 minutes thinking about that irony to death. Good times.

The most magnificent experience I've had with weed was life changing. I suffered from anxiety and depression and one night, my sister and her boyfriend decided I should hit the bong just once. Well this hit was something fierce, as I had gone into a paralysis after a few minutes and thinking I was about to die, of course that was very unlikely. I could not speak nor open my eyes I could only hear. I remember being in this confined open space; Like I was inside my mind. I was feeling utter terror and I could hear my sister freaking out, that was no help lol. Her boyfriend however was calm. I remember him saying that everything is going to be okay, just enjoy it. Then all of a sudden my playlist from Spotify was playing. I couldn't do anything but enjoy every little detail about the songs. I was feeling happy. Like happy beyond comprehension.

Eventually I was standing up and I saw myself there on the couch sleeping. I still could hear the music though. I was weightless and could do whatever I wanted, even fly. I went into the air and observed the city from high above the land. Just then, I hear Flower Duet by Lakme and began to see these majestic fractal butterflies gracefully fluttering all around as this deep dark blue sky was illuminated with so many stars. This world was amazing and I never wanted to leave. I flew over the city and eventually saw my childhood neighborhood. While I was flying I encountered this person who I have not seen before but their presence felt very familiar. Like we've known each other since birth. They said, "It's so good to see you again! Having fun?" Soon enough though I found myself back in the room I was sleeping in, feeling heavy and then my memory fades there. I woke up, still listening to music. I was still trying to recuperate from the knock out. But that dream, it felt pretty real and it felt really nice.

Since that day, I've a better understanding of who I am need am no longer depressed. I wish I could visit that dream again though. It truly was beautiful and I want to know who that person was. Weed gave me a clear sense in my mind and allowed to me to piece problems I've been having in my life. I wish I could do it more often, but I have no time really.

if you have anxiety, it will either amplify the anxiety or tackle it in its tracks. its all about finding what strain works the best for you. if you have anxiety its most likely you'll want an indica which is more relaxing and since sativas get your brain thinking you'll most likely want to avoid them. but also remember strains are only as good as the grow. you can get a seed off of the best weed plant on planet earth and without proper light, nutrients, and care it will be low grade which no matter what strain it supposedly is it will just be mostly plant matter with little to know medical benefits. I'm talking about stress (seeds, sticks, and leaves) if it's a dense, nice smelling, bright bud it's most likely good, just be careful for pesticides, mold, and over dryness. but don't be to quick to judge some may not look the part but will be just as strong as others. at the end of the day no one can tell you what strain is best for you except yourself, but from personal experience (my anxiety was debilitating couldn't leave my house or even relax in my own bed without feeling like I'm having a heart attack) I'd go for the og's. H.A OG, Tahoe, Tahoe OG, Skywalker etc (a lot more info on the leafly app). Risks of Marijuana Use:

Though you may have heard otherwise, marijuana can be addictive: Nearly 10% of people who use it become dependent on it. It isn’t clear whether marijuana is a gateway drug that makes people more likely to try harder drugs like cocaine and heroin.

The amount of THC in marijuana has gone up in recent years. Most leaves used to contain between 1% and 4% THC. Now most have closer to 7%. Experts worry this might make it easier to become dependent on or addicted to marijuana and it also strengthens many of the drug’s mind-altering effects.

Even if you buy from a legal, state-regulated dispensary, it can be hard to know exactly how much THC or other compounds found in marijuana you’re ingesting, so the effects can be unpredictable.
So is weed bad for you?

Although there are 421 chemicals in marijuana, but there is one chemical among the all which is considered to be the most mind-altering chemical called delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol or THC. This chemical is the psychoactive ingredient and also addictive in nature. The intensity of THC content in marijuana after the cultivation phase ranges from less than 1% to more the 30 %. The higher end of this range has been increasing dramatically making it more potent and addictive in nature. Thought process, memory, time perception, concentration level, sensory and motor movement are affected the most due to marijuana use. Chronic marijuana use has found to have strong association with increased rate of anxiety, depression and schizophrenia. Moreover, high doses of marijuana can also cause acute psychotic reaction.

Scientific research shows that there are risks, especially for teens. Marijuana affects a person’s judgment and can impair his or her abilities. For those who use it regularly, it can lead to poor academic performance. Marijuana contains 421 chemicals but the main mind - altering chemical in marijuana is delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinon or THC. The brain parts which are most affected includes those that impacts thinking, memory, concentration, time perception and sensory and coordinated movement. Chronic marijuana use has found to have strong association with increased rate of anxiety, depression and schizophrenia. Even the high doses of marijuana can result in an acute psychotic reaction.
Shahzad Rehmat counselor at http://willingways.org/

Marijuana in the end provides dissociative / psychedelic effects from it's effects on Serotonin uptake and NMDA antagonism, amongst many other changes in dopamine, norepinepherine, GABA etc..
If you keep that in mind while using it, you learn to ignore the negative side effects eventually as they are a simple distraction created by your mind, it's a simple side effect of the drug.

Marijuana needs to be recognized and treated as any other psychedelic substance and you will have very few negative side effects from using it, here are some tips ---->

* Be in the right environment, if you can't handle yourself well around people, than don't smoke pot in a public area or around others, try it by yourself in a calm environment.

* Have a glass of sugar water or cup of chamomile tea around incase things do manage to get too panicky, both of these negate the effects of marijuana through different and not yet fully understood mechanisms - Benzodiazepines can also be used as emergency treatment for panic, however you must exercise caution if you use them as they are HIGHLY addictive.

* Avoid being extremely high around people who are not under the influence of drugs themselves. This reduces the paranoria and feeling of looking out of place.

Alright guys I am going to tell you my experience with marijuana.

I was 18, I was curious. I kept thinking about trying these stuffs because I want to experience it myself. So one day while in college I asked one of my friend, who smokes marijuana if I can join him. He said yes we we went to his house.

He took out crumbled marijuana and rolled a joint and gave it to me. He told me to inhale it. So the first time in my whole damn fking 18 years of my life I inhaled. I didn't get high, and he told me I did it wrong. So I tried the 2-3 times, I didn't get high. But the substance started to kick in after my 4-5th tries. I felt dizzy, relaxed but only by a bit. Btw he smoked too. But he's like totally lost it. His eyes were fking red, his face muscles are all relaxed. He's like a fking sloth, too tired to do anything. I got high only by a bit, so it is still bare able. About half and hour later he called McD and we ordered some burgers and fries and I went home. 

I  was not satisfied, so I told him I wanted to try it again. But this time we did it in a "hotbox", or his car. We walked to the parking lot and went into his car and for christ sake it smells like drugs as soon as you enter in it. So he blasted some EDM music and took out marijunana and once again rolled it into a joint. This time I was ready and I learned my techniques and I inhaled the smoke. 7-8th inhalation was all it took to make me high. 

My legs and arms went numb as I just sat on shotgun. My eyes went red, my face got tired, everything was just soo relaxed. I didn't think about anything at all, as I just sat there trying to fall asleep. He got it bad too, just like a fking sloth. Then after some time we got out of his car and I went straight to the nearest sofa to sleep. Jesus christ I tell you every thought was racing through my mind. Some crazy conversations I had ever. I saw like spinning elephants and doge. Overall I just got fking tired on the outside, but fking crazy on the inside. 

Back in the train, I got scared because I don't want anybody to suspect me from taking drugs because my eyes were still fking red, so I closed my eyes and slept. I slept all the way throughout the commute until I reached my home. 

-----

My advise, if you wanna try it. Go somewhere secluded or quiet. I did it in public and it fking sucks!!!! I had to take so many precautions to avoid getting arrested. It is not addictive as that is my 2nd and last time I will gonna smoke it. It's been a few months.

Ok let me tell you something,
I've been smoking weed for 2 years now, and for 1 year daily. I have had the experience of getting high for their first time to a lot of people; friends, unknown people, and my sister.
And i have a conclussion: it depends on how much you enjoy new experiences, my friends, who are fun and like to party, they really enjoyed trying it and they still smoking today, maybe not daily but regularly. My sister oh my god! She is a quiet person, not really go out a lot but i talked to her about the benefits of cannabis and she really wanted to try it, but as i said she doesn't like new feelings, she hates how it feels to be drunk, have never smoked a cigarrete, long story short, she's not that into feeling different than the way she feels sober, and she did not liked weed, maybe because it was her first time but she didn't like to feel super relaxed, she said she felt silly, and that she will never do it again.
She was the first person to ever say that to me, i have smoked cannabis with at least 15 persons (for their first time) and they all loved it, or at least enjoyed it and have done it again.
SOOOOO if you have never smoked cannabis and you want to know how it feels:
First, ENJOY IT you will have to be ok with this new experience
Do it in somewhere you feel safe, so you wont feel scared for someone smelling it, or idk.

You will feel very happy, funny, and relaxed also its a great time to listen music and think about life
Oh and of course: eat, ride a bike, TAKE A BATH!!! And watching something funny in tv

So be open to new experiences, remember this will never affects you the way it does tabacco or alcohol

Here's why weed sucks.  You finish a year of uni so you're like "cool, I've worked hard, stayed clean and now I can smoke again and have an awesome summer."  Then the fucking cops bust a few tons across the country other people finish uni and buy in bulk everything the dealer has and you end up not being able to buy any at any price for the entire Summer.  I'm back at uni now so I have to wait another fucking year. 
It's not addictive but for me it's the drug that doesn't have a negative as long as I'm not studying.  I get what's called "second day stupids" if I smoke, but I almost don't get it if I vape.  What it does is that the day after you smoke weed you are stupider: you can't focus properly, remember things well and it makes it very difficult to do mental arithmetic.  That's why it's not a drug you can combine with school if you are actually getting high on a school night.
You need to exercise a little caution and probably stay away if you're the kind of person who sometimes suffers from depression and anxiety as these things can surface quite strongly under the influence.  Other than that, if you're off school and work that requires good thinking and you don't have any depression or anxiety issues I would "highly" recommend marijuana over alcohol.  It's better, there's no hangover and you can't die.  The only thing that could make it better is if it didn't affect your memory so much.

This is exactly the opposite of what I read in my textbook! made me go back and check a couple of other resources and be sure that this is wrong! No offense to puthead fellows! I just mean it is SCIENTIFICALLY wrong about how cannabinoid receptors work. They are actually released by the postsynaptic dendrites (surprisingly!) to tell the presynaptic axon to slow down! so one can imagine they are very useful at the time of sharp pain to control it a little bit. so when you add more cannabinoid matched transmitter to the system, its gonna slow down and almost turn off those synapses! that's why we are not that smart and sharp when we are high! Although some of the synapses are inhibitory. so for those synapses activity goes up. But I don't believe any of thing good comes out of this second process (like relaxing pain for the first type), because usually the brain naturally doesn't inhibit good things. Cannabis causes a complete release of melatonin from the pituitary at the first hit or two. Melatonin, crucial for dreaming, causes the dreamy not euphoric like with heroin effect pot is so famous for. During daytime, the melatonin quickly metabolizes into serotonin, which is the happy relaxer effect pot is also famous for. No cannabinoid is a duplicate of anandamide but they are close enough to set off a cascade of anandamide release and production. This is a very healthful thing done in a healthy, organic way.

Marijuana has this marvelous ability to enable you to do a single activity possibly better than you have ever done that activity before; however, as good as this can feel, we must be careful, as life is hardly ever composed of only doing one thing well, but our safety is contingent upon our ability to do a great number of things well, nearly all of the time, as this ensures we actually make it through life all in one piece!

Example:  Driving a car, can be a most wonderful journey, on a scenic mountainous region, where one has the ability to see a great distance on the highway one is driving upon, as with darting looks out into the Ocean or large Lake to see the beauty of the green/blue water, its clarity, and the people and their yachts moving about, some on skies, others jetskies, or some having dropped anchor, for a party and a sun-tanning spell.  The marijuana euphoria difference, can make this a most beautiful experience; but, if suddenly from behind you, someone is speeding, and you can see as he signals to pass you, he is going to pull out into an uncoming car, he'll need 1000 horses to pass in time with nothing but rock on that passing side, and "he's acting like he's utterly blind!"  WELL here then is also a problem for you!  Somebody not stoned on pot, might turn to the passing car, and with a gesture of the left hand tell him to slow down, and pull in behind you instead of heading out to pass you, but with these additions now added to your Sunday afternoon drive adding up, the stoner only feels safe enough now, to continue driving with both hands on the wheel, the normally multi-tasking brain only in first gear, having little to do but sit there in wonder as to what will be the outcome of the situation!

This is the single worst problem marijuana brings into the life of the user, and this is an ever present side effect, with the user  regardless the reason he is using pot, whether for pain relief he truly needs, or whatever other reasons medical marijuana might be the best drug to allay the user's present problem!  THIS needs to be made perfectly clear to all medical marijuana users, and because I have been a pot user in the distant past, and have often experienced this freezing side effect, which makes you realize some situations none could have known would occur, become major nightmares when THC does the many different things concomitant with pain alleviation, and the rest of the blessings medical marijuana usage is well-known for.  And so, while under its effects, the very best thing you can do, is stay at home with loved ones, and enjoy the analgesia with those who mean more to you than anyone else, in the safety of your own home!

Guys smoking weed does in fact have negative consequences. After doing a cold turkey for about 10 days I still have a cloudy/hazy mind and am somewhat after-high, it's hard to concentrate and I behave differently than I normally would. Yes you won't die of an overdose or get harsh physical withdrawals like with alcohol or other drugs but saying that it has NO negative effects is simply a lie. Good video, but a little short for a substance with so much controversy around it. If you want to know more facts about cannabis, take a trip to Google Scholar. Make sure you look at methodology and who funded it, not all studies are equally valid. Avoid political sites. If you go to advocate sites, they're going to tell you it's some kind of miracle substance, and if you go to anti-pot sites they're going to trot out all the standard War On Drugs arguments. Possible bias: I'm for legalizing pretty much every drug and educating people on the risks. I hate paternalistic policies that assume the populace is too stupid to make rational decisions. From what I've read, it's not that damaging if you vaporize or use edibles, but consuming large amounts every day is a stupid idea unless you're a chronic pain or cancer patient. Using it before your brain matures appears to cause problems, so kids, just leave it alone. Everybody else, do your research and use responsibly if you decide to.

Neuroscientist here. A lot of people in the comments are getting a lot of love for promoting cannabis. I just felt the need to tell everyone the actual pros and cons of marijuana, coming from somebody who "reads articles" for a career.
Pros:
-It can be used to reduce pain, increase appetite, and in some cases may be helpful to cancer patients*.
(I will not cite helpful for depression here, simply because manic depressives are exact kind of people whom you do NOT want to try any potentially emotionally addictive substances. *Furthermore the chemicals in marijuana that can help cancer patients can be easily isolated and bred into strains of marijuana that have no high, and thus less cognitive dissonance. So all of those cancer surveys you guys are floating around to tote weed is like me sending out aspirin articles and telling people that it's good to eat the willow bark it comes from. The strain that gets you high isn't supposed to be used for cancer.)
Cons:
- Smoking anything at all will put tar in your lungs. I probably don't need to go into how bad that is for your long-term cardiovascular health.... Keep in mind that cardiovascular health problems kill more US citizens than any other cause of death. 
- A lot of people seem to think that marijuana only negatively affects your brain in large quantities. This is totally false. The key heuristic in examining the detriments of marijuana is not the size of the dose, but rather the frequency. Smoking about once weekly is enough to significantly decrease adult IQ potential for teens and drastically increase chances of early-onset dementia and Alzheimer's disease in you later years.

(Newsflash, your brain has evolved for millions of years to be what it already is, and any repetitive use of any psychoactive or psycho-depressive drug will result in sub-optimal performance in the long term.)

(THC) Tetrahydrocannabinol is the main psychoactive ingredients in cannabis that induces the psychological effect. When the compound enters the bloodstream it targets the central nervous system, altering the brains neurological function. Although the (THC) property emanates from a natural plant, the potency alters the brains processing system. The (THC) property binds to the naturally produced cannabinoid receptors in the brain, altering how the receptors process information, causing irregular or disruption of the brains natural regulating mechanism. Recently they've discovered ways to harness the DNA structure of THC to create synthetic drugs. A chemically induced imitation of a process that propagates naturally between the harmony of botany and the ecological system. Intriguing indeed. From reading the comment's below I have come to the conclusion that the world I live in has been nonconsensually raped by what appear's to be main stream media and thirteen year old's who have a basic understanding of how Google search work's. 
Saying all Marijuana smokers are brain dead, is one of the most narrow minded statements I have read. Just by doing 5 minutes of research you will see physiologically what occurs to the brain when you smoke, and if you have an IQ higher than that of a Gerbil you will notice that the Axon's are not depleted or strained (unlike most drug's out there). The video gave a very basic context to what occur's when THC is introduced into our blood stream, and yet I still read comment's saying "this video made no sense", "pot head's smell". 
I'm sure these are the same people who consume alcohol (make's you act like Luiz Suarez and make's your breath smell like Guantanamo Bay floor's) or over consume incredible amounts of food (not even going to get into that topic from what I've seen during clinical placements in hospitals).
My teen life sucked, I was depressed and never found a valid reason to get out of bed in the morning, I always felt like the dumber person in the room, my family was beyond broke, I went to school hungry most days. And surprise surprise I tried weed (If you felt how I felt, you would swallow rock's if someone told you it would make you feel better.) Nothing was instantaneous, HOWEVER, I for the first time in my life felt interested in life, friends, science, hell...I even got curious as to how the stock market works.
Long story short, I've been smoking for eight year's now. I went from a loner and being depressed to having friends and even making into the School of Medicine in University of Otago (not before finishing my nursing degree). Now this is the internet and anyone can claim to be whom ever they wish, so I don't expect anyone to believe (I would do the same in most cases). If this is how we people treat each other these day's, then I have no doubt in my mind the world will spiral to a endless pit of anger and resentment, one that is somehow stronger than the evil that exists today. First of all, so little is known about the affects of marijuana or how harmful it is to the human body, and the information given in this video is too basic for anyone to come up with a proper conclusion. Truth is that marijuana can be medically beneficial to people with nerve pain and helps chemotherapy patients control nausea and vomiting. But there's no evidence that marijuana works better than other therapies.

Anyway, most people using marijuana don't use it for medical reasons, they use it to get high. Over 5 million American use marijuana EVERY DAY. And frequent, prolonged marijuana use has been linked to depression, psychosis, anxiety, and other mental disorders, especially among teenagers. Even infrequent pot smokers were more than twice as likely to develop schizophrenia as non-smokers. I smoked cannabis around 4-8 times because I felt like I was depressed and I was told smoking weed will help me relax and be positive. While the first time I Smoked very little that it helped me relax a bit, I felt no change in my brain, or rather my body because I smoked sucha low dosage.

Let's fast forward, my fourth usage I smoked a lot more than I had before since my friend I was smoking with had persuaded me to smoke more by saying smoking more will make me less depressed which was a big PLUS for me. So I kept at it. 

The effects of this were unlike anything I have ever had in my entire life, the other 3 times I had smoked weed it was just my body feeling heavy, and I was laughing more than usual. But this time, I was not able to process time properly, I would look at my phone and what should have been a 40 minute walk only took 2 minutes to me, it was 9:38 when I looked at my phone, and suddenly I appeared at my destination at 9:40. But when I looked away from my phone and back suddenly time jumped a whole lot from 9:40 to the proper time of 10:14 or some random time I have already forgotten. Everything my friend said, I would only process around 10 minutes later and reply to that comment, confusing my friend. 

I would have constant black outs, one I had when we arrived at A&W. I was standing at the counter for a large portion of time apparently, and suddenly i was sitting down eating what I apparently ordered. I couldn't figure out what was happening to me. I wasn't able to recount for those black outs. Suddenly I blacked out again and had an outer body experience watching myself walk to tree and urinate, I finally came back to my mind frame and to my surprise I was an elementary school parking lot, apparently my friend told me we were just silently walking there after he suggested it. 

After I went home(Somehow can;t even puzzle that together either.) I fell asleep, woke up and apparently the effects never left, I still had moments where i would phase in and out of conscious thought, and would arrive at a destination that used to seem longer but thanks to my random black outs have been less lengthy.

I smoked it again another few times because of my anxiety and further increasing depression on this matter, and now I actually don't feel the same. I can't structure a proper sentence, my mind has a hard time learning new things, and recalling past memories has become a daunting and much harder task than it used to be, I feel like my memory has been affected and altered, and my perception of time has been horribly changed as well. I feel.. in a sense dumber than before and I can't properly describe things. This post itself took me a large amount of time just to write. I cannot perceive things the same anymore.

Am I actually dumber because of Weed smoking? Will I ever get back to normal? Will the toxins provided by weed that are now in my brain ever leave? Or am I like this until I die?

Let me share personal knowledge with you my brothers and sisters.. I am 17.  The first time i smoked weed was when i was 15.  During this time, i lost all drive and my grades fell to a SHOCKINGLY LOW 3.45 gpa.  At this moment, my parents who found out said there was probably no hope for me.  At this point i cleaned up my act and lived a sobre summer.  School started again and my grades fell even more when i didn't smoke.  I lost my purpose in life and didn't have drive.  I was being drug tested so i didn't use weed.  Instead, i took LSD.  I took 1 tab, and while tripping i stupidly took the other 11 tabs, freaked out, thought i was paralized, and went to the hospitle.  It took almost a full week to get better, but when i did, I WAS REBORN!!!  I shot my current gpa up to a 4.0 and became an outgoing and loving being who realized my true loving soul!!  I have wonderful drive and found my way through LSD.  I can't describe most of my lessons learned, for most things learned were emotions of insanity, love, and raw fear.  I stared straight into my inner soul and it chewed me up and spit me out.  I was literally reborn.  Afterwards, i eventually gained trust back and havn't been drug tested in a while.  I had a 23 ACT score.  Average and nothing to be proud of.  I started losing my motivation again after about 5 months since the LSD trip.  I went on to pick back up weed, shrooms, and DMT, and now my ACT is a wonderful 32!! I have truely found myself and the wonders of the universe through psychedelics.  Many people who use them completely abuse them and don't use them for purposes i do.  I use them to fine all the wonder in the world and as a way to help me find my true spiritual consciousness.  I learn and grow from them.  Sure, i have some of the greatest times of my life on them, but i don't use them for the high.  I use them to give me a greater appreciation of life, nature, and people all around me.  I use them not to escape this world, but to connect with it and think for myself.  I have never been more alive and currently smoke weed every day while i continue my journey and accomplish far more than the majority of others my age.  I have greatly surpassed my fellow young adults and it is truely thanks to psychedelics.  Not that they MADE me this way, but that i was and have been able to use them as tools to appreciate and grow in life.  I love you all.  These drugs are definitly not for everyone, and are abused, but they have truely been something special and positive in my wonderful life.  For those of you like me, i have one word of advise.  Don't let others control you.  Be your own man and be your own original self.  The only thing holding you back is yourself and others, and for the most part, you have control over both of those.  Namasté brothers and sisters. :)

My mom managed to get her hands on a marijuana cookie, and after consuming it, she laughed for a few minutes, cried for a few minutes, then got on her knees and started screaming a bunch of hate. She hallucinated off/on for at least 22 hours. Whenever she did manage to stabilize the first time, she was concerned over an experience where she apparently "died", "went to hell", and that "nobody was there" but her. A terrifying thing to hear at 3am over a dimmed lamp.

Throughout the hallucinations she couldn't stop talking, her mouth just wanted to speak on whatever topic it could gets its hands on. Her body was in no shape to handle the drug. When she was finally in control of her body again, she compared the drug to having an exorcism, and vowed to never try anything like that again.

Sativas over indicas seem to trigger anxiety attacks ONLY when I smoke, never when I eat either. I have recently learned a little bit about decarboxylation. Could the higher psychoactive content be the trigger? Could it be my own thoughts, my environment, or a chemistry issue? I am 36yo now, in my 20's I had smoked A LOT of phx ditch weed(sativa dominant). I loved every bit of it aside from the perfume, mold, ammonia, and urine smell usually accompanied with our mexi flower from the south. That said, my weed only recently started triggering massive anxiety attacks after the onset of anxiety itself. Up until about 2009 I had never dealt with an anxiety issue. Time went on, I started to blame weed in general. Then we in Arizona voted in the MMJ program, I joined NORML, and started learning more about all the other compounds in this stuff. I noticed the higher the CBD count, I was less likely to have anxiety from smoking. I am curious, in the act of eating it, is there an omission of the psychoactive compound "THC"? This is a pretty thin explanation so I'll just hand out the information I've personally gathered out of curiosity. I disagree with this video only in that I think people can keep those accelerated experiences - it's responsible for a lot of creativity in the world I think. Really big with music people - I think something about the physical process of playing music works well with it. 

Smoking anything can clog the lungs but the amount of weed one smokes is nothing compared to the amount of work a cigarette addiction puts your lungs through - anyone without asthma will probably be fine, so beyond that, THC is very powerful antioxidant and acts as a neuroprotectant for this reason - it may even prevent brain cancer to a degree, but that's incredibly hard to study.

Nothing has been discovered with weed that is harmful, it appears to be an associative toxin - the purpose of these chemicals in nature is probably to discourage hebivory. Most herbivores are prey animals and become very distressed by a chemical that makes them sleepy and confused because it makes them likely to be eaten, anything that makes them unable to flee is upsetting and to be avoided - after this first exposure they avoid the very distinct smell of marijuana blossoms, which otherwise would have made a sap-rich energy-packed meal for it. So the key is actually the smoking part - the fire changes it, it burns up some of the lighter cannabinoids that would be involved in making you the sort of paralyzed-stoned one can get when he eats two extra pot brownies because he didn't think the first one was doing anything. Happy, but unable to move much or speak and giggles at everything for four hours. I imagine this is the response the plant evolved to produce and the "high" part is mostly due to our special way of getting to the cannabinoids.

There's also two other things to consider, horticulture and tolerance. Whatever the hundreds and thousands of bred and cross-bred strains of weed are now is highly different than their genetic source - not unlike the way all dogs descended from the wolf, yet, clearly have become tons of other things. Weed has been bred for bud size and cannabinoid content for so long that the weed we raise is probably 50 times as potent as what you'd find if you really cared to go search the Hindu Kush mountains for a wild kush bush, and like dogs, people's opinions and techniques have pushed it in all kinds of directions. I have had weed I swear to god did nothing but make me feel like I was insane (Jack Herer, ick!) , but this is rare I think just the result of a few breeder's bad taste - massive THC content with nothing else going on. On the other hand I've had crossbreeds I swear to god were high art, most of them ending in "Kush". Here's the thing - THC is far from the only cannabinoid and I think ideally a good strain is one that's expressing a strong amount of other cannabinoids too, especially CBD. I've had a strain (Harlequin) that was raised for pressing to make CBD rich pain-killing oil, I mean smoked them, you really don't get a big high - until you realize you can mix it with kush and it's the best thing ever. So when scientists and whatnot talk only about THC and it's effects when talking about weed it's like - like we're not even talking about the same thing. There's probably 50-100+ substances yet to be described by anyone floating around in your average bowl and they've barely studied the ones they've already discovered. 

And then for tolerance, well, what this video describes is more like smoking the first couple of times - before your body produces metabolites from the cannabinoids and circulates them (this is what they detect with drug tests). They mediate the high and make it much less intense and racing, you're able to hold onto those cool thoughts if you choose. It's important for non-stoners to remember that stoners are not getting NEARLY as high as said non-stoner got the one time they tried weed, not even a tenth that high.

comment_text: +Yomil Dank Watch Sci Show's video "your brain on pot". I don't use these drugs but some of my closest friends use marijuana daily. I have noticed in a few that they have become a nightmare sometimes due to paranoia proven to be caused by the drug.

Too many people believe that since cannabis smoking isn't as bad for you as smoking cigarettes that it must mean cannabis smoking isn't bad. Now, while getting high a couple times actually does have more benefits than cons, it is in no way beneficial to smoke on a regular daily basis. I used to smoke every single day, for a couple of months actually I smoked multiple times a day. I suffered from issues such as: depression, social anxiety, insomnia, and even schizophrenia. So, weed itself isn't bad, but the overuse of it is. Much like anything else in the world. If you eat too much broccoli, you get a kidney stone. If you drink too much water, you could scientifically drown. Moderation with marijuana is key to using it.

If you don't want to read any facts on the effect on the brain, then stop reading this comment now. 

Our brains all have this thing called the "Endocannabinoid System." It is responsible for various functions we use in our day-to-day lives, such as: sleeping, appetite, depression control (let's call it that), brain development, stress response, and many others. What happens when you smoke cannabis is you introduce your brain to the plant's "Phytocannabinoids." These extra cannabinoids are seen as so similar to the brain's that they are used in the same way. The more you use cannabis, the more external cannabinoids your brain is receiving; allowing for less production of it's own "Endos." This only happens after a prolonged time of constant cannabis smoking, so it's not as serious as smoking crack or meth, but it will kind of, "dull" your life - so to speak. 

Conclusion: Getting high 2-3 times a week is going to do you no more harm than just a little weakening to your lungs (that doesn't even make that much of a noticeable difference honestly). But the overuse of it will have effects that seem like they are "running you down." So, weed is indeed a good thing, just know how to maintain your usage.

This explanation of the THC's effect on the neuron refractory period is wrong. No drug removes refractory periods from neurons, they are there as a result of electrical discharge when the neuron goes from the Action Potential depolarized state of 40-50mv down to -80mv (refractory voltage) and then back up to -70mv (resting potential). THC increase the output of various neurotransmitters that get released when there are enough depolarizing ions filtering through the protein-ion channels in the cell membrane. Through frequent use the neurons may down-regulate or up-regulate (more or less receptors for these neurotransmitters, but the action potential will never dissapear, if anything, only quicken, but don't quote me because I'm not familiar with that literature.

Negative, that is not how memory works. Memory works like a muscle, the more you use it, the better your ability to recall later will be. This is why things like reading a book, quizzing yourself, and studying for a test are good for you. You lose what you do not use.

If you poke your hand, and then poke it five minutes later, some of the neurons that register the poking the second time will be different from those that did the first time. Circuits are set up and torn down, on demand, all the time. That's neuroplasticity.

I like this guy, but this video is terribly misleading. Endocannabinoids are produced by the cell bodies and dentrites of the post synaptic neurons, and act as retrograde nts. They inhibit the presynaptic neurons (which themselves can be excitatory or inhibitory). This either strengthens another pathway, or decreases it (learning). HOWEVER, smoking weed floods the body with endocannabinoids, which then do not act on the target cells alone and cause impairment of memory, learning, and attention

Interestingly, itching while falling asleep is completely psychosomatic, a way for our subconscious to make sure we're actually falling asleep, not dying, similar to limb jerking as you fall asleep

Research shows that being tickled is actually an excellent defense mechanism. The struggling side of it trains our bodies to defend itself against the most natural attacks, ie, grappling, maiming, etc; while the involuntary laughter encourages people to tickle. Vsauce have an amazing video on this

Also, like I said, that's just the initial symptoms. At about 36-48 hours without dosing, I experience symptoms extremely reminiscent of mild opiate withdrawal (and this is coming from an ex-addict, so I know what I'm talking about) - hot/cold sweats, anxiety and general discomfort to the point of being nearly bedridden - all very mild, but definitely things I wouldn't be experiencing otherwise. I'm not knocking weed at all, but the notion that it causes absolutely zero dependency is debatable.

I have been taking mostly medical doses of edibles (i.e. I don't always notice a distinct high, unless I take enough) every day for about six months now, for anxiety and depression. My body has become so used to the constant sedation, that when I don't dose for about 12-24 hours, I start to become VERY overstimulated and my anxiety skyrockets. It's not quite the feelings of impending doom like with benzo withdrawal, but it's definitely above my usual baseline if I'm not "on" anything.

(cont) In contrast to alcohol, which tends to increase risky driving practices, marijuana tends to make subjects more cautious. Surveys of fatally injured drivers show that when THC is detected in the blood, alcohol is almost always detected as well. For some individuals, marijuana may play a role in bad driving. The overall rate of highway accidents appears not to be significantly affected by marijuana's widespread use in society. (source: drugpolicy)

There is no compelling evidence that marijuana contributes substantially to traffic accidents and fatalities.
At some doses, marijuana affects perception and psychomotor performance – changes which could impair driving ability. However, in driving studies, marijuana produces little or no car-handling impairment – consistently less than produced by low to moderate doses of alcohol and many legal medications. What are the long term use effects of marijuana and how can you treat them?

There are none. The active molecules found in cannabis so closely match the natural chemistry of your body that they themselves are flushed from the body in exactly the same way dead blood cells are expelled through urine.  And following the active processing period THC in particular will store in fat cells to be slowly expelled with waste.

As far as science has been able to determine there are no permanent effects to cannabis use whatsoever.  Psychology is not science yet.

There are types of intelligence that aren't quantified by a standard IQ test, but here's why that's irrelevant. IQ tests test the same metrics whether you're a marijuana user or not-- so the effect measured is still genuine. If it shows a reduction across the board in a standardized IQ test, then it's reasonable to postulate the same effect would exist in untested types of intelligence as well. But even if those were completely unaffected, the tested metrics are still lower after marijuana use.

Well, the reason marijuana use has to be regulated (i.e. not driving or operating heavy machinery under its influence) is not because you're likely to become violent, it's because your reaction times are inhibited. Yes, alcohol is worse than marijuana in that regard, because not only are reaction times inhibited, but so are other inhibitions, so alcohol CAN lead to violence as well whereas marijuana won't. That doesn't make smoking a bowl and getting behind the wheel safe in any way.

Then you know they are very bias and only cover a few types of intelligences that the test-writters deem most important(usually intelligences that they already excel in. I think IQ tests very are useful, especially for standardized testing, but are not a 100% accurate measure of intelligence and they discourage creativity.

While I don't think it should be illegal, the mere fact that it resembles something naturally occurring in our bodies has nothing to do with whether or not it's harmful. We are like 70% water, but if we drink too much water, we can die. Too much iron, and we die.  Opiates like Vicodin contain chemicals similar to what we already have in our brains, yet they can be addictive and harmful to our livers (among other things).
And did I mention wolfsbane has medicinal uses?

Of course, there is the issue that molecules which are near identical are not, in fact, identical, and can have radically different effects due to their differences.
And then there's the issue, as has been pointed out, of dosage. Wolfsbane is a naturally occurring plant which in small doses is mildly unpleasant, but proves fatal in large doses.
The point is, the scientific community has yet to make a definitive ruling on the toxicity of cannabis.
